remarks.para: This class provides helper methods for asserting the validity of arguments. It can be used to reduce the number of laborious if, throw sequences in your code.

The methods can be used to ensure that arguments are not . The overloads can be used to ensure that strings are not or empty. The overloads can be used to assert the validity of enumeration arguments.

remarks.para: This method can be used to ensure that an enumeration argument is valid for the context of the method. It works for both flags and non-flags enumerations. For flags enumerations, must be any combination of values specified by . For non-flags enumerations, must be one of the values specified by .

This method is much faster than the overload. This is because it does not use reflection to determine the values defined by the enumeration. For this reason you should prefer this method when validating enumeration arguments.

Another reason why this method is prefered is because it allows you to explicitly specify the values that your code handles. If you use the overload and a new value is later added to the enumeration, the assertion will not fail but your code probably will.

member.param: An array of all valid values.
member.exception: If is not present in , or (for flag enumerations) if is not some combination of values specified in .

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.HelperTrinity.ExceptionHelper
member.summary: Provides helper methods for raising exceptions.

remarks.para: The ExceptionHelper class provides a centralised mechanism for throwing exceptions. This helps to keep exception messages and types consistent.

Exception information is stored in an embedded resource called ExceptionHelper.xml, which must reside in the Properties namespace for the assembly in which the for type is stored. For example, if the root namespace for an assembly is Company.Product then the exception information must be stored in a resource called Company.Product.Properties.ExceptionHelper.xml

The format for the exception information XML includes a grouping mechanism such that exception keys are scoped to the type throwing the exception. Thus, different types can use the same exception key because they have different scopes in the XML structure. An example of the format for the exception XML can be seen below.
remarks.note: This class is designed to be efficient in the common case (ie. no exception thrown) but is quite inefficient if an exception is actually thrown. This is not considered a problem, however, since an exception usually indicates that execution cannot reliably continue.

member.example:
The following example shows how an exception can thrown:
var exceptionHelper = new ExceptionHelper(typeof(Bar)); throw exceptionHelper.Resolve("myKey", "hello");
Assuming this code resides in a class called Foo.Bar, the XML configuration might look like this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<exceptionHelper> <exceptionGroup type="Foo.Bar"> <exception key="myKey" type="System.NullReferenceException"> Foo is null but I'll say '{0}' anyway. </exception> </exceptionGroup> </exceptionHelper>
With this configuration, a will be thrown. The exception message will be "Foo is null but I'll say 'hello' anyway.".

The following example shows how an exception can be conditionally thrown:
var exceptionHelper = new ExceptionHelper(typeof(Bar)); exceptionHelper.ResolveAndThrowIf(foo == null, "myKey", "hello");
Assuming this code resides in a class called Foo.Bar, the XML configuration might look like this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<exceptionHelper> <exceptionGroup type="Foo.Bar"> <exception key="myKey" type="System.NullReferenceException"> Foo is null but I'll say '{0}' anyway. </exception> </exceptionGroup> </exceptionHelper>
With this configuration, a will be thrown if foo is . The exception message will be "Foo is null but I'll say 'hello' anyway.".

remarks.para: This method can be used to validate all publicly-supplied enumeration values. Without such an assertion, it is possible to cast any int value to the enumeration type and pass it in.

This method works for both flags and non-flags enumerations. In the case of a flags enumeration, any combination of values in the enumeration is accepted. In the case of a non-flags enumeration, must be equal to one of the values in the enumeration.

This method is generic and quite slow as a result. You should prefer using the overload where possible. That overload is both faster and safer. Faster because it does not incur reflection costs, and safer because you are able to specify the exact values accepted by your method.
